Award.AwardTitle: Novel Vanadium Dioxide-based Self-Sensing Microactuators: Modeling, Control, and Application to Micromanipulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this project is to investigate modeling and control methods for vanadium dioxide-based microactuators, to enable robust, precise, and efficient control of these actuators. Vanadium dioxide is a smart material, whose unique actuation potential has not been noticed until recently, and it has advantages of high volumetric energy density, superior durability, and excellent repeatability. However, pronounced hysteresis from phase transition, together with sophisticated, coupled electro-thermo-mechanical dynamics, presents significant challenges in the control of vanadium dioxide-based microactuators. The research approach consists of creating a model that captures hysteresis across multiple physical domains with high fidelity and minimal complexity, developing algorithms for self-sensing and for controlling systems with non-monotonic hysteresis, designing and fabricating vanadium dioxide-based multi degree-of-freedom micromanipulators, and experimentally validating the developed modeling and control methods.

By exploiting the synergy between control theory and novel actuation materials, the project will advance the state of the art in both. If successful, the results from this award will facilitate the realization of the full potential of vanadium dioxide-based actuators in areas such as microsurgery, microrobotics, memory technology, and microassembly, with positive impact on biotechnology and micro/nano-manufacturing. Besides curriculum enrichment, the project will provide unique interdisciplinary training opportunities for graduate and undergrad students. Both PIs have a strong track record in recruiting and advising female and minority students, with the co-PI himself being a successful role model for Hispanic students. A number of outreach activities will be developed to engage K-12 students and the public, to pique their interest in science and engineering. Examples of these activities include teacher training, interactive demos, and ?dancing with the micro stars?, where students act as choreographers and make arrays of vanadium dioxide-coated micro-cantilevers ?dance? to music through laser scan programming.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this award was to develop modeling and control methods for vanadium dioxide (VO2)-based microactuators, and thus to enable robust, precise, and efficient control of these actuators in different applications. VO2 is a smart material that goes through a reversible, thermally induced solid-to-solid phase transition, during which drastic changes occur in its mechanical, electrical, and optical properties. In particular, the change in mechanical property can be exploited for actuation, namely, using thermal or electrical input to generate force or motion. VO2 actuators have advantages of high volumetric energy density, superior durability, and excellent repeatability. However, sophisticated electro-thermo-mechanical dynamics and a pronounced nonlinear behavior, called hysteresis, resulting from phase transition, present significant challenges in the control of VO2-based microactuators.

This award resulted in new mathematical models for capturing the hysteresis behavior in VO2 material and VO2-enabled microactuators, along with inverse compensation schemes for approximately cancelling the hysteresis effect. Feedback control with self-sensing, where the electrical resistance of VO2 was used to infer its mechanical state, was demonstrated.  The self-sensing scheme utilized a composite hysteresis model that captured the electro-thermo-mechanical coupling. Experiments involving VO2-enabled cantilever benders, with integrated heating elements, were conducted to validate the modeling and control schemes.

In addition to the VO2 micro bending actuators, this award contributed to the development of more sophisticated VO2-based devices, including micro mirrors and tunable filters. Comparing with other electro-thermally actuated micro devices (for example, differential thermal expansion-based bimorph actuators), the VO2-enabled micro-electro-mechanical system (MEMS) devices showed significant advantages in energy-efficiency.

This award also led to a number of advances in theory and algorithms for modeling and analysis of systems with hysteresis in general, that were validated experimentally with VO2 microactuators. These included compressive sensing-based parameter identification for Preisach hysteresis operators, and optimal model reduction for generalized Prandtl-Ishlinskii hysteresis operators.

Collectively, this award contributed to 13 journal publications, 6 conference papers, and 3 PhD dissertations. The results from the award were also disseminated through Youtube videos and invited talks. The project provided training opportunities for 7 PhD students and one exchange student, and it contributed to K-12 outreach activities such as lab tours and presentations. The technical advances made in this award will facilitate the realization of the full potential of VO2-based actuators in areas such as microsurgery, microrobotics, memory technology, and microassembly, with positive impact on biotechnology and micro/nano-manufacturing.
